number of helpful: 280 of 302 people (93%) found this review helpful
content:
er 25, 2013
												THE city simulator. It's old but it's the best one out there if you ask me. Even though the graphics aren't full 3D they are still surprisingly high definition and it is fun to zoom in close just to look at the buildings. The graphics really do still hold up. I was honestly surprised.The gameplay is fantastic if you're into this genre although there are a few problems. Some of those can be fixed with mods, which there are plenty of. There's nothing that would ruin the experience, just some nit-picky things that would make a couple of things easier in the long run. The modding community is great and popular mods are totally worth getting even if some of them change the game mechanics quite a bit. If you new to the genre I would recommend you first play a city or two without mods to get the vanilla experience. For the fans of the genre: mod to your hearts content. You can pull a lot of extra depth out of the game with the right mods.Depending on how you play once you reach that final stage with your city where everything runs like a finely oiled machine it might feel like you've reached the end. Some may continue to micromanage every little aspect for days to come but I recommend starting a new city. I personally prefer going for a visually impressive city rather than the most efficient one. Sim City becomes more of an information management/puzzle game if you aim for the most productive city. It is more enjoyable to create something visually pleasing.You will waste days managing your city once you get sucked in. Prepare your calendar accordingly. This among my favorite games of all time.(I have probably played SimCity a hundred hours back in the day. I still have the disc!)----[Rating weighted based on the genre]----Story: -/5 (There isn't one.)Gameplay: 5/5Challenge: 3.5/5 (Depends on individual styles of play.)Discovery: 1.5/5Replayability: 5/5Aesthetics: 4/5Visuals: 4/5Atmosphere: 2/5Music: 5/5

content:
y 31, 2014
												Looking for City Building Fun? Look no further!Pros - Not Sim City 2013- Looks very good for a game from 2004- Gritty, Realistic, Approach to City Design - Large Selection of Terrains- Easily Adjustable Settings- Amazing Soundtrack- Modding Kit makes for a longer gameCons - Terrible System Optimization for Newer PCs- Borderline Broken Demands on Easy and Medium Difficulties without ModsI have been playing this game for years, picked it up on Steam last Summer. I have to say, the biggest issue I have with it now is Optimization on my PC. You cannot run the game past 1600x1080 without massive screen tearing and Region View Issues and Terrain Glitches (Purely Cosmetic.) Overall I would say the only other noticable issue, after 10 years (10 year old game better than a game made in 2013, who the ♥♥♥♥ knew?!) is the broken system demands on Easy and Medium. Both difficulties will eventually go in complete negative demand, with no possible way to recover, unless you install mods, which leads to my next point. Even after all these years the modding community is still huge, so much effort goes into so many mods. Honestly I see no reason not to buy this game.9/10 - Great game if you like City Planning and Building games.

content:
2, 2015
												First off I will say that my hour count is not correct, I played this for hundreds more hours on the disc version of the game. I caved in for the Steam version so I don't need my optical drive installed.This game is my all time favorite game, nothing has come close to beating it. This game released more than 10 years ago still holds up very well thanks to the modders and the community of this game. If you don't like something about the game then search Simtropolis for a mod to fix it. As a beginner the modding might seem a bit scary. Tons of dependencies! What do I do?!? I started by installing the mods slowly. First the NAM mod which is essential, then other things such as added trees, buildings, etc. You don't need to install every mod at once to have fun in this game. Just be sure you install all the dependencies to the mods your installing, or else you'll get dreaded brown boxes all over your city (no fun!).If you need to compare this to modern city builders such as Cities Skylines or Simcity 5 I still think that it beats it. Maybe it's just because I have a great nostalgia about this game. Cities Skylines is an excellent successor to this, but it just can't replace this game in my heart. Compared to Simcity 5, this game is amazing. Bigger cities, doesn't need Origin, and no major "Agent" problems. Whether you want to build an uber realistic city or just a casual city this game is definitely for you. It goes on sale for $5 during the sales, so if you can wait then I would recommend it. If you want a 3D city builder with easy to install mods Cities Skylines is probably for you. Also, before running this game check out the guides on Steam on how to run this on modern hardware. My system only needed some tweaks, but yours might need more. My system specs: AMD FX 6300, 8gb DDR3 RAM, AMD Radeon HD 7870, MSI 970a-g43 AM3+ motherboard.Get ready to waste hours of your life creating the perfect interchange!Update: Since this review I've upgraded my PC to a i5 4690k, 24gb DDR3 RAM, MSI Gaming 6G GTX 980ti, and MSI Gaming 5 motherboard plus Windows 10 and the game still works great.

number of helpful: 97 of 105 people (92%) found this review helpful
content:
4, 2014
												I spent years playing this game for PC. The CD is still in my laptop right now. For those that don't know, SimCity is the originator of being a mayor, placing down your roads, zoning area for buildings, watching them grow and balancing the budget. This isn't for everyone, but to a lot of us, this is huge fun and SimCity 4 is probably the best in the series.This is all single player, instead of the more current SimCity 2013 that is focused on multi-player. The game can cycle from night to day, but its just a look and doesn't seem to do anything special. You have terrain control like previous versions of SimCity before you start each game.You start out in a region map of dozens of land plots. Large, medium and small. You pick a plot of land and make your city. You can then save that city, load the region and start up a new city on a different plot of land or go to a previous city. Why does this matter? Because you can trade between cities, you can export and import water, garbage, energy and so on. Not just that, but the sims / citizens can travel back and forth. Such as living in one town and going to another for work. You'll also have pollution effects that seep into other towns as well. This is all single player, so you need to jump between cities. Because two or more towns can thrive off of one another, you can put your heavy polluting industries in an extremely profitable town on their own with no residents living there to complain about how awful it is. There is no need for police, hospitals or schools if no one is living in your industrial city. Then just make some mass transit system for them to get to and from work.When you play, you have full control from the start with only a few things locked away unlike Cities XL that requires your city to grow before it unlocks things for you. Because you have full control, that may set you up for failure quickly. Highways, big hospitals, deluxe police stations and so on cost big money and until your city is big, you should keep it small. Once your city grows, the game has ways to tell you that your hospital is too small, such as your staff workers will go on strike. How do you know if its too small? Sadly you can't just hold shift and click the building, you need to click the ? and then the building. It seems tedious, but you'll see what the building can handle and adjust its budget. If you can't adjust the budget high enough, its time to make a bigger version of the building or just plop down another building to do the same thing.You need to keep your budget balanced, everything will cost monthly money, so you either need to cut spending from places like roads, schools, utilities or raise taxes, which might make some businesses, commerce and residents run to away from your city. When you lower taxes, of course people move in, but then your hospitals, schools and so on will be overcrowded, your buildings will grow larger. Its beautiful.The game will tell you what kind of zones you'll need, such as low, medium and high density residential, commercial, industry and even agricultural. Its your job to plop them down. It has a graph to show you if you need more and less. If you need less, raise taxes for them, or replace the zone with a new zone. Luckily the game makes it easy to replace zones.There are all sorts of charts and maps, such as pollution, both water and air. Crime, fire safety, land value and so on. If you want to raise land value, put down police, fire, schools and so on. Then add parks and various things to drive value up. Replace dirty industries that pollute with cleaner industries like medium density manufacturing.You can also click on zoned buildings to see the crime, water, power, pollutants, and even the driving pattern of where the residents go and where the employees come from. Its a very nice feature. Especially if you're trying to reduce traffic. You have control over roads, avenues, streets, highways, trains, subways, busses and so on. Its fun to see just how far people will ride a bus to work. The game has plenty of charts too, in order to demonstrate how far the average drive is, how much garbage you have, the age and education of your population. Its all a lot of information.On top of that, you have advisers that will tell you what's good and bad about your city. The game sadly uses pop up windows to tell you what's up, but thankfully there is a setting to turn it off, or else before you know it, you'll have nothing but popups. Instead you can look at the ticker at the bottom of the screen and even go into the advisers section to see their specific needs.After all is said and done, you can then summon a natural disaster (or truckasaurus) to come and destroy your town. Why you'd want to? Just for the laughs I guess. Because this is the deluxe edition, it comes with Rush Hour expansion pack, which gives you the ability to take over vehicles and drive them on the road. Not first person, but still from the normal almost top down perspective. This content gives you missions that will give you cash and other rewards, but really, it doesn't feel like a great addition. Its just there.This game is a classic, but after 10+ years, I don't think that its aged very well. After months of playing Tropico and Cities XL, those games just seem to run smoother control wise and have explanation to them. Having a hot key for pause would have been nice. Fires break out in your town extremely frequently, no matter how good your fire coverage is. It just breaks the flow of the game, you need to send your fire fighters out to stop the fire and wait while they put it out. That's just not fun.There are also a few minor bugs, but some that will crash the game. Since there is no autosave, you can lose an hour's worth of progress if not an entire city.It is still an enjoyable game and I can recommend it more than SimCity 2013. Is it worth the $10 - $20? No and yes. If you enjoy mayoring sims, you can sink days and months into this game, then its worth it, but you should wait for a $5 sale if not cheaper.

er 24, 2014
												Since I won't touch SimCity 2013 (and Origin in general) due to all the problems and irritants those bring to the table, SimCity 4 is the most recent choice of SimCity games that I can really play. It is dated and has some issues such as lack of widescreen support and the other usual issues older games have with newer OS's, but that can be fixed. And despite that, from what I have heard, this game is still better than the recent remake even without all those online issues that game had, with more features and larger maps to build cities on. Also this game has a strong modding community (Simtropolis) with an insane amount of new buildings and stuff to add to your game. Ideally you want a good PC if you plan on making super-big cities and don't want your game to lag like crazy, but even my poo PC can more or less handle this fine despite having built cities more densely populated than any currently existing on Earth.So if you feel the sudden urge to build cities, and yet realize that so many city building games of the past few years have a host of glaring issues, then SimCity 4 is your best choice. Have fun! :D

content:
9, 2016
												I've spent probably thousands of hours on this game before I even had a Steam account (big Sims fan in general). It wasn't until I got it a few months ago that I actually even had a clue on how to even properly play the game. But moving along from memory lane, this game is still amazing for being as old as it is.Having been released in 2003 and made available on Steam in 2010, this game and even the game series itself can honestly be seen as revolutionary for the city-building and simulation games that have followed since the original simcity was released. This game was almost in a way ahead of its time and in my opinion STILL outshines many other city-building games (maybe I haven't played enough but who knows) that try to recreate in their own sense the management strategy that SimCity brought upon the world of gaming. The replay value of this game is beyond compare, for something different is always awaiting you, and the mods are endless to build off what the game originally provided.The beauty about this particular game is that it can be both a "place anything anywhere and watch what happens" sort of game but it also can be a complex square by square city builder where you perfect every detail and the style of your houses to the taxes each individual industry and residential type pays. Many modern city builders try to play off this but say unlike City Skylines where you have to work your way up to get more land to begin with, there are countless areas and regions of all sizes for you to use and connect and even create to eventually have the ultimate city or state or nation or whatever you wish. Plus the music is pretty damn great as well. The game just allows you to almost settle down and lose yourself. SimCity 4 has to honestly be my FAVORITE city-builder out there, as it still is for many. But that's just a personal opinion. For it's current price of $19.99 and replay value that is seemingly endless, i'd say it's worth it.11/10 would obliterate city again and restart when things start to get out of hand

content:
2015
												TL;DR: Took a military jet to the nuclear plant and recreated chernobyl. Built safe zone city one region slot over. Raised volcano in safe zone city and burned all survivors. 10/10 would hijack expensive military equipment againActual review (yes, cities skylines taken into comparison):This is the supreme reigning king of city builders. While in time it will likely be beaten by Cities: Skylines, as of now this is still the best in terms of purely easy to use UI, fun things to do (the TL;DR is easily possible ingame), sheer number of mods, and customizability. I have thousands of hours in on the simcity series as a whole and only bought this on steam as another version (I still use disc/GoG versions more). The majority of the hours went into either 3000/unlimited or this version, both pre-and post-rush hour expansion (included in this one).Keep in mind this is also the HARDEST of the simcity games, and even on easy it is very possible to screw yourself over several hours in with a chronicly failing city that slowly decays into destruction on its' own. It's also one of the most fun, however, as SimCity 3000 did away with the terraforming (mostly) of simcity 2000, and this was the first (of 2) in the series to introduce regional gameplay with multiple cities interacting on a massive map. Big difference between this and the latest simcity, however, is that in addition to preset regions, YOU create them. You can terraform them, modify their size, city layouts/sizes literally using microsoft paint, plop the cities, set up the city interactions, etc. The only thing missing is the multiplayer, but with the city sizes in this being arguably 16 times larger than simcity 2013, that more than makes up for it as you will sink dozens of hours into filling up a map and customizing it the way you want to with what is also the best UI in the series, doing a lot of the work for you and letting you optimize where and when needed.So, why would I even recommend this over Cities: Skylines?AS OF RIGHT NOW. As of the time of this review, Cities: Skylines is a fantastic city builder with a mass modding community and...that's it. There is no regional play, terraforming has to be modded in to be performed mid-game, the art style is VERY bland and probably has less than 100 buildings the game can call upon to place down in zones, the UI when placing roads and such has a lot of issues that make it much harder to use than it should be, there's a lot of missing features that have to be modded in, and the ability to truly customize the city is significantly lower than in this game. While I will continue to play cities skylines, I have the game heavily - and I mean HEAVILY - modded to even begin to replicate the magic of SimCity 4 and its' predecessors. I feel like the game was designed around being better than SimCity 2013 which in some aspects (art, soundtrack, pure...fun things to do, customizability) it isn't, but the major missing things in SimCity 2013 (city sizes, DRM, lack of map editing) were what drew people in. That, and the game expected it so it would have a large modding scene to fix what the developers didn't add. That's understandable, as the dev team is VERY small for Cities Skylines, but the thing is that SimCity 2013 lowered the bar of city builders to a point where Cities: Skylines was no longer just below it, but far above it.Understand this: I WILL continue to play cities skylines. And I believe it is a great game. But it is going to take a monster that can do what Cities Skylines did to fix the SimCity 2013 formula, and also take the time to add in what SimCity does RIGHT, before there will be a city builder capable of dethroning this one. It has to look and play the part, and give the user the ability to have FUN above all with customizability, destruction, and other random things that occur (like piloting a military chopper guns blazing into your own house...like you can in this game).If you do NOT own this game and are a fan of city builders, I highly encourage you to get it now. At a price of $20 for the base AND its expansion, the only downside is compatibility with modern OS systems, and it is still possible to make it work with a bit of stuff done. What you're ultimately getting is the definitive city builder, and what remains the king of city builders that many of us fondly remember from our childhoods and will continue to remember. This is a timeless game in ways others simply cannot and likely will not ever live up to.

number of helpful: 34 of 37 people (92%) found this review helpful
content:
3, 2016
												The simulation genre wouldn't be what it is without the venerable SimCity series. Since 1989, the many entries in the line have allowed people to become virtual mayors and design cities of just about any shape and size, limited only by the contents of the game itself. They've come a long way from the original and branched out in many different ways across platforms, and not every instalment has been a success. SimCity 4 is often described as the last great SimCity, and with that and my own remembered fondness for it I decided to see how it's held up over the last 13 years.Honestly I find it a little difficult to describe the nature of SimCity, because it is such an elemental part of the genre. You lay down roads, outline zones for development of homes and businesses, build power plants and fire stations, balance your taxes against your utility expenditures, and grow your little town as large as it will go. These are all core concepts pioneered by the series, but 4 presents them with greater refinement. Each individual service building like police stations and hospitals can have their funding adjusted to meet local demand, so you can build expensive services and then scale them back to what you can afford until you need more. Zone density can also be scaled up or down without destroying existing buildings, allowing them to grow or shrink as needed.It's one of the purest and accessible presentations of the city-building formula out there, with no production chains or unlockables to concern yourself with. You build what you want, where you want, with the only limitations being space and money. SimCity 4 is far more generous than its predecessors with the latter, allowing you to start with enough money to cover most of a map right from the outset. And with control of individual building funding, it's a simple task to keep your budget in the green. The maps remain plenty large enough for bustling metropolises, but they're also connected by regions, allowing you to get a grand overview of your cities, granting your people the option of commuting to other areas, and creating massive metro areas with interconnected cities and neighborhoods.The end result is a robust and expansive city-builder limited only by its age. SimCity 4 is still a 2D game, despite some voxel trickery to make it look deeper and more dynamic than it is. You're laying everything out on a grid, which makes building at anything other than right angles either cumbersome in the case of roads and rails, or impossible in the case of buildings. The terrain is deformable and conforms to your constructions to a point, but if your landscape is very hilly at all you'll end up with houses built on soaring foundations larger than the dwelling itself, and beaches and piers plunging off of your coastlines into the deep. The detailed pixel art of the buildings is impressive, and each is rendered from four directions so you can rotate the camera, but they look chunky at max zoom and indistinct at a distance.Despite these shortcomings, SimCity 4 remains one of the finest city-builders you can lose yourself in. The steady pace of construction matched with the enormous variety of buildings and services to work towards means you can spend hours crafting a single city without having to wait for long periods or growing bored. The data displays show you everything you need to understand how your city operates, from pollution and traffic overlays to the actual routes your citizens take daily. There are even optional driving missions you can take in your own city and Sims you can move in to get more personal feedback. It might not be the prettiest or slickest offering anymore, but SimCity 4 has stood the test of time and remains one of the most addictive and comprehensive city-builders on the market.

												This game is the bomb diggity, even after 13+ years.PROS:++Great, mostly balanced gameplay++Good looking 2.5D graphics++Endless amount of mods and assets++Has full 1080p support, in a *13 year old game!*++Runs pretty well on nearly anythingCONS:--Hard to get working properly (I suggest looking for the SC4Launcher and 4GB patch if you want to really boost how the game works)--Can crash a lot without the right settings--Mods are difficult to install w/o Steam Workshop support--The simulation is often finicky, but granted, there was only so much devs could do back then (pickup the Network Addon Mod for improved traffic simulation)--The tutorial isn't super-helpful in helping you understand how the regional simulation worksOverall, if you're looking at this vs Cities: Skylines (and have a PC that can run C:S), go pick up Cities. However, I highly suggest dropping this into your wishlist and waiting for a sale, which is quite often on this title, because this game has a certain charm that I don't think any city builder has or ever will replicate.

												When I bought this game half a year ago, I wasn't familiar at all with city-building games, but it was on sale and SimCity was of course a known franchise, so I bought it. When I started up the game for the 1st time I saw that I sometimes suffered from unexplainable graphical issues (colored lines ramdomly appearing on the screen). I went on. Then I noticed that the game sometimes chrashes (it happened to me about 10% of the times that I play it). I went on. Then I saw that I had been playing for hours. I went on.This game is just so good that I dont't really mind these issues that I have from time to time. It is just so nice to start from scratch and create the city of your dreams (or the City of Death, for that matter). But that's just the start. After you're done with one city you will want to start up another neighboring city and connect both. and then a third city. And a fouth. There is just so much replayability because every city has different terrain. And while I can say that it's definetely not easy to make (and keep) your city healthy , it's not too complex to handle.Since I bought this I have played more than 140 hours in 5 months time. For someone who also plays numerous other games, that's quite something. So yes, I'd definetely recommend this game if you have only a remote interest in city planning/management. It's already quite cheap normally, but when it's on sale there should definetely be no excuse for not buying this game if you think you will like it. It'll be worth the money.

content:
28, 2016
												This is the definitive version of any SimCity. Much better than the sequel SimCity: Societies.TL;DR: Even though it is 13 years old it is still one of the best examples of a city builder today. I'd rate it  8/10 This game was one of the major contributors to Cities:Skylines as it is Paradox's main inspiration for the game. The U-Drive it Missions are unique to city builders wherein you can interact with your city on a much more indepth level. The economics aren't simplified and the advisors offer advise that can actually be used. For being a very fixed camera in an isometric setup, you get plenty of gorgeous angles and shots. The modding community for this game is still alive as far as I recall, although a lot of it is becoming harder to find certain things such as Network Addon Mod (NAM).  The main drawbacks of the game are mainly due to its age. Unlike Cities it isn't based on both a free building and grid based snapping system. This is solely grid based and it has a very big drawback, bridges. You can only build bridges certain directions and in straight lines. The other main drawback is performance issues on certain new machines and crashes. But I believe you can find a patch around for a fix for the crashes. A minor more nit-picky issue with the Steam version is that unlike a box you don't get a pamphlet that gives good advice about RCI and how to increase and meet demand, but again you can probably find a picture of the RCI pamphlet on the internet.Overall the game is excellent. Even though my hours on the Steam edition are lackluster, playing on the two-disk box version is where most of my hours really come from. As said above,  8/10

content:
er 28, 2014
												We still have yet to see a true successor to the immense scale offered by SimCity 4. It has everything from the peaceful zen of settling a farming village in rolling hills, carving out a bustling coastal metroplolis, or the dirty fun of managing the man-made mountains of your region's garbage city.The modding community has really made this game shine. At the minimum I recommend the Network Addon Mod (NAM) because of the improved traffic simulator - even if you choose to not increase the road capacities or include new highway and rail components. A full NAM install will add a good bit of content, so choose carefully when doing a custom install if you dont want your menus to get too bloated.I have also managed to get the game running smoothly on my modern hardware (3770k + Radeon 7850). This game is known to erroneously detect moden Radeon HD 7xxx series GPUs as the old non-HD 7000 series. In the game's GraphicsRules.sgr file I commented-out the entire section on "radeon slow path for partial depth buffer copies" and added a new rule for the "AMD Radeon HD 7000 Slow-Down Fix" posted in the simtropolis forums - this resolved choppy scrolling issues.I also use the following launch options set in steam: -intro:off -CustomResolution:enabled -r1920x1080x32 -d:directx  -w -CPUcount:1These options: disable intro, enable and set custom resolution, directX video output, windowed mode, use only one cpu.

ry 10, 2015
												A quiet country town, a polluted industrial city or a modern and technological metropolis? The choice is yours.SimCity 4 is a city building strategy game that after 10 years (!) from its release remains one of the best in its category (personally the best). Your job is to be a major with the power to decide everything, from the terrain morphology to social politics of the city, it's urbanistic development, the transport ways and public services, from budget for education and health care to the one for police, etc...Very intuitive, you must provide jobs for the three social categories of inhabitants in the game (low wealth, medium wealth and high wealth), places to live and roads of communication to reach their job.Despite you are a sort of God or dictator, some council members will help you to administer the city, warning you of critical problems regarding specific categories such as traffic, education, pollution, public services' coverage and so on...PROS: A very good, intuitive simulationActive modding community Very detailed and great building varietyEnjoyable for a vast audience due its flexibilityFantastic graphic and low requirementsGood sound and effectsCONS:You can't play without modsSometimes could be frustrating Occasional crashes and rendering problems on modern machinesVERY ADDICTIVEConclusion: you will hate EA for the sequel of this fantastic game :D

r 18, 2016
												I grew up with this game :) I read some of the negative reviews of this game to be objective.Most of the not recommended recviews are about new hardware and Windows 10. I do not exactly know if the game works well with high end graphics and operating systems but i will assume it works after some work arounds.Because if you can run this game and if you are a fan of city managing, this game is the most detailed game i know. Considering Cities XXL, Cities Skylines and City Worls. I am kind of a City building veteran :)This game is pretty hard and complicated. You will most probably bankrupt you first 4-5 cities. you have to master the income and outcome balance and peoples happiness. Every desicion counts. Every single unit on the map is important. Reources management and city planing is crucial.The game has advisors if there is something urgent to be adressed. And they might have good ideas too but do not go for all their ideas :) For example there are fires in the game and you have to dispatch units with your own hands. Sıo the advisor pops up and goes crazy in the middle of the screen. :)The game has terraforming, water and air and noise pollution, land value and desirability to guide you. Neighbouring cities can exchange resources for income. Schools and hospitals are covering an area, so you have to adjust and optimize residential and commercial ares acoording to these two. Fire and police stations are also effective within their reach. But you can dispatch fire truck from a corner of the city to another.Patient is the key to success in this game. Do not think you can just install the game and rise skylines. And i hope you can run the game on new operating systems and hardware.

number of helpful: 19 of 23 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 6, 2014
												Playtime (with mods such as Network Addon Mod, and Colossal Addon Mod (NAM and CAM), is absolutely limiteless.  As a testament, I am still playing this game 10-11 years after it's release.  I don't feel compelled to move to the always-gotta-be-online new simcity.  I don't need snazzy 3d for a casual game when I get all the feedback and playability this way.  There are so many different ways to set things up.  Totally flat worlds, or mountainous terrain, or even a city by the bay.  HUGE cities in this game, with proper modding as described above can support over FOUR MILLION people on a single CITY.  It's very reasonable to expect to have 50-100 million people in a large region if you devote time into this. With the NAM mod mentioned above, you can build absolutely breathtaking realistic freeways just like you use on your commute to work or commuting to a shopping spree (heh).  With CAM mod, you can build huge skyscrapers and zone denser than ever before and really have a reason for all those highways.Build Seawalls, Docks, Highways and Raised Road Viaduct/byways, Mass transportation suched as raised rail/monorail/subways/ground light rail and connecting all these together (mods may be required for some of these, but they are very worth it).  Build photo-realistic cities that you yourself wouldn't mind lodging up in.  The mods alone make this game easily worth it's 20 bucks (US $) without a doubt, and if it's on sale, you'd have to be a fool not to pick it up.  Simcity 2013 is like a graphically enhanced sample, of what this game is.  If you enjoy Simcity 2013 but would like to grow bigger, higher, more populous cities, and have complete control of the road network of your dreams, this game is for you!  You can spend hours just trying to mod this, there are thousands and thousands of different ones to choose from.  Start with NAM and CAM as stated and start looking around for what peaks your interest - with one caveat:  Watch those dependancies!  Simtropolis, Sc4Devotion, and Simpeg are all great places to go look for mods, free signup is available, may be required and is outside of Steam or EA service's control.

I own a physical copy of it, and I recently picked up this Steam copy... definitely one of my favorite games ever.You need to mod the game in order to make it playable, and the game tends to crash, lock up, and run slowly. There's no autosave and you'll probably lose a lot of hours of gameplay. Loading a custom region is cumbersome, installing mods is archaic, and the whole thing is just clunky. Using some mods will require literal hours of patience... ask me about custom highways or building a mass transit network. You can install a massive amount of options for mass transit and building variety. It's intoxicating, if you're into it.If you just want to build a pretty city, you're going to need to work slowly and learn how to do it. This game honestly isn't friendly or accessible for new people... But if you work at it, and you enjoy the genre, you're going to love it.

content:
ry 2
												Despite being fourteen years old at the time of this review, this game is still entertaining. I think a huge part of it is how well it ages - it came out in 2003, but there are no musical or UI or humor clues that would tie it to the early 2000s. It's still one of the best city simulators out there, and if you're willing to add these to your launch options (or Google platform specifics):     -CustomResolution:enabled -r1920x1080x32 -f -intro:off you won't experience any issues with the game crashing, plus you get to play it in HD. The modding community is still alive and well, somehow. But most of all, SC4 just looks good. The art style is cohesive, the colors and day-night cycles are on point (mostly), and despite almost everything being 2D pixel graphics it looks beautiful, especially if you know how to arrange your city. My one issue is that the game, like any single-player simulation, feels a little lonely sometimes. And if you get creative with Dropbox you can play a sort-of multiplayer, but there's no true MP built into the game. It's a good thing for the most part, because there's none of the always-online ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t that comes with a lot of "single-player" games these days.Basically, if you like any of the tycoon games, Civ, or model railroads, this game's for you. You can raise the difficulty if you want a more hardcore planning-focused experience, or mod in some demand multipliers if just want to build some nice interchanges.

number of helpful: 18 of 22 people (82%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 5, 2014
												Honestly this is probably my favorite game of all time. If you played the new SimCity and often thought "Huh, that seems like a dumb feature," you'll probably find that SimCity 4 alleviates most of these complaints. In my mind, there are three key differences between this game and the newest SimCity:1. Non-agent based simulation: SC4 instead opts for a big-picture, numbers-based simulation. You'll find that this opens up many features that are highly preferrable to the agent modelling in the new SimCity, while still maintaining an acceptable level of simulation. This leads into the next difference.2. City / Region size: With the less intensive processing involved in all the population dynamics, cities and regions are MUCH larger than the new game. There are no bare spots between cities; the whole world is yours to control. Want to make a complex highway system, servicing key neighborhoods and moving high volumes of traffic? Go right ahead. Highways are woefully prebuilt in the new game. Would you instead like to focus on public transit? The options are all there and in greater depth than the new SimCity. As a result of the larger size, the game feels much more open to creativity despite the lack of curved roads.3. Modding: While the newest game just recently announced support for offline mods, you'll find that SC4 is far better off in the modding community. Many overhaul mods are available to give more transit options, better modelling, more buildings, and other assorted features. If you don't like something about this game, it's likely there's a mod to fix it.Those three features are the main reasons why SimCity 4 is a far more rewarding experience than the new SimCity will ever be. Considering all this, and that SC4 can be had for $5 very easily, why would you choose the new one?  I'm just now picking up a copy on Steam because who knows when my old CD will stop working from damage or something.

content:
ber 15, 2016
												+++++++++++++++ Review +++++++++++++++This is THE greatest city builder of all time. Today's reiterations like Cities: Skylines can't touch the beauty and intricacy of this game. Its "2.5 Dimension" style graphics style will probably never be seen again, and it's something you'll have to experience to appreciate. Note that there's a huge difference between 'SC4' and a 'heavily modded SC4' - the community is still very much so alive on Simtropolis and SC4 Devotion, making great free addons to this game with real world buildings, restaurants, road addons, landmarks, trees and everything else you can imagine. Hardcore players of SC4 are typically sandbox builders and don't care for the actual game aspect - you can create some pretty mind blowing scenery with this game and the right mods. With that being said, it's a game with an insane amount of replay value...not just beacuse it has no "end," but it's a relaxing scenery builder that will give you a great deal of therapy through the years.+++++++++++++++ About the Steam Version of Sim City 4 +++++++++++++++If you're like me and have been playing SC4 from the original disc, it's worth re-purchasing it through a Steam sale to get this patched version, because SC4 does not work well from the get-go. You will need to do a little work to get the game to run on Windows 10, but this will simply take a couple minutes...here's what you need to know:+++++++++++++++ Getting Sim City 4 To Run On Modern Day PCs +++++++++++++++The version of Sim City 4 DX that you get from Steam is "1.1.641.0", which means that the old "EP1 Update" (UPDATE_SKU1_TO_P1.EXE) and "SC4Update4BAT" (SC4Update4BAT.EXE) are already included, and you won't have to hunt them down on the internet. These patches were necessary if you had the old CD version of the game; otherwise, buildings would not light up during the night time cycle.Once you install the game, you'll have to edit its Steam launch options, which is pretty quick and easy:- In Steam, click "LIBRARY" in the main menu.- Next, right click "SimCity 4 Deluxe" in the right-side menu, and choose "Properties"- Right within the GENERAL tab is a button called "SET LAUNCH OPTIONS..." - click it.- In the field provided on this final pop-up, paste in the following variable string:-w -intro:off -CustomResolution:enabled -r1920x1200x32 -CPUCount:1 -CPUPriority:high(These variables are: -w (wide screen), -intro:off (skips past the annoying intro that runs every time the game opens, -CustomResolution:enabled -r1920x1200x32 (this tells the game to run at your monitor's resolution, change it if you have to), -CPUCount:1 -CPUPriority:high (this is the most important part...Sim City 4 cannot run on more than 1 core, so you have to force the program to run on only one. Otherwise, the game won't run).+++++++++++++++ Getting Mods for Sim City 4 +++++++++++++++Mods make this game what it is - you won't believe how different it will look once you've added some custom content. The two best sites on the internet for mods are Simtropolis and SC4Devotion. Even after all these years, the communities for SC4 are thriving on these sites. They'll also have plenty of resources that tell you exactly how to unpack and install mods - it's pretty easy.The essential mods you'll really want (or have?) to get are:- "NAM (Network Addon Mod)": adds a ton of new realistic roads, interchanges, ramps, etc.- "SC4 DAT Packer": makes the game more stable by centralizing your mods into one big file- "Cheats By Buggi": allows you to input a bunch of different cheats that will make your life easier if you're looking to play this game in sandbox mode+++++++++++++++ Standalone Mods for Sim City 4 +++++++++++++++There are two notable standalone mods for Sim City 4. They install as separate programs:- "SC4 Terraformer": this program is really old and a little clunky, but it will all you to hand sculpt a Sim City 4 map by drawing mountains, valleys, hills, etc with your mouse across any or all regions - even over borders, which is impossible to do in-game. The regions can then be imported into your game.- "SC4 Mapper": This program lets you modify the size of the regions in a current Sim City 4 map. If you wanted regions to be bigger or smaller, or if you wished that the borders of a certain region were located somewhere else (like, one region on your map that is not 90% water and 10% land), you can edit them with this program.

content:
, 2016
												The crowning achievement of the SimCity IP; SimCity 4 Deluxe Edition delivers all of the best features and systems of each of the previous versions into this better and improved offering.  Some would argue that SimCity 5 was a more improved version, and to them I say this, Origin was not inolved in the making of SimCity 4 Deluxe Edition and therefore is the much improved title!  The need to be always connected to the Internet in SImCity 5 killed the game for me, I love the option of Online Interaction but hate that I cannot play the game as a single player Offline; thanks again Origin!  The addition of Sim interaction in this game was wonderful, the ability to add your own Sims to your cities and get their oppionions about specific things was sorley missied in this title's predicesors.  Having played all previous versions I had always longed for an in-game method for dertermining which things about my city were small annoyances to my populace but not major enough for my advisors to complain about.  These things would affect your mayoral rating as well as have an effect on which Sims would move into and out of certian areas.  Furthermore, the addition of the "Piloting" mechanics added a new layer of depth to the game while offering new construction options to the player for accomplishing different missions.  If you loved any of the previous SimCity games, this one will not dissapoint!

content:
ry 8, 2015
SimCity 4 – Deluxe Edition is a city building and management simulator. Elected Mayor over a city-to-be or existing city, manage city development by laying roads, plotting land and zoning, constructing public service buildings and maintaining financial balance as you thrive to build a megalopolis.Pros: You are giving a lot of flexibility, from zoning density to street type. As your city grow, additional selection of power plants become available, and additional needs are requested such as water treatment facilities, trains and subways, ports and airports, as well as a variety of educational establishments, health and emergency services. You have a good list of additional tax options, each with their own downside and benefits. Keep a balance between how much financing you can afford, and how much you need, to give to each of your public services (as a whole or per individual buildings). More special buildings and landmarks become available as your population rises. You can even connect your different cities togetter with your streets, highways and railroads, if they are located on neighboring tiles on the map.Cons: You are limited to determining individual land plots and zoning type, with little control on what will actually be built. You may have small shops and fast food being build on high-density commercial areas you were planning to have towering office buildings on, or maybe cheap low-cost apartment blocks will appear on residential zones you wanted luxury condos in. City interconnection requires you to actually build the neighboring city, its streets not necessarily being aligned with each other's connections. Tax revenue is hard to come by, and you'll often catch yourself speeding up time and wait years to get enough money to continue building without resorting to high-interest loans. Public service coverage is radius-based, which forces you to finance overlapping territory, or leave out coverage in-between your schools, police stations and hospitals.Verdict: ★★★☆☆ - It's up to youThe amount of micro-management you have, plotting individual land plots, and the amount of effort it needs to reach actual high-density buildings, makes SimCity 4 – Deluxe Edition more of a town simulator than a large urban sky-scrapper city simulator. Still, it remains a good example of the genre and the best game in its franchise.—————————————————————————This was just my opinion.If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up, and feel free to check out more of my (purely opinionated) reviews.

content:
er 16, 2015
												For an older game SimCity4 is worth playing in my opinion.  I know a lot of people get frustrated with this game because it tends to lag a little once your cities get bigger but, I dont't think its the end of the world its still very playable. Within this series, I've played SimCity 2000('93) when my brother introduced me to it then I moved on to SimCity 4 and I've been hooked ever since. Another thing I've noticed about this game is that, you need a lot of patience and most people don't bother and they give up. The reality is SimCity 4 is very strategic because, you must think way ahead of time when laying out your city and think of future problems like traffic. I'd suggest taking your time and not try to rush growth of your city because, you'll run out of funds very early. It takes time to build a solid foundation so that you can have a decent mount of monthly income. Everyone who plays this game figure out what strategy works for them but, don't let the occasional frustration steer you away. Overall, I think this game is very fun to play and you can let you imagination go wild with the extra downloads you can add to your city.

content:
1, 2014
												This game is incredible. The Graphics are very detailed and realistic. You can build more than one city on the same map. Not to mention importing your own Sims from "The Sims" into the game. Your city just doesn't sleep like that of SimCity 3000. You see your people walking about and running their daily lives, like walking their dogs, Driving to the supermarket, Driving their kids to school even going to church!The biggest improvement that I saw in SimCity 4 were the disasters. In SimCity 3000 you had like what? 4? In SimCity 4 you get over eight disasters. The best part is that you can control and decide where your Tornado goes. You also get Volcanoes that erupt, Erathquakes that bury houses and split open the earth, Meteor showers that leave everlasting craters andLightning Bolts, Fires, Riots, Floods, Mudslides, Bank Robberies and even Car chases. You get to choose you terrian styles. You can ahve an African style with Rhino's and Giraffes. Sometimes they can even stampede into your city.The other great thing about SimCity 4 is the terrian tools. You can sculpt gorgeous, Lagoons, Cliffs, Craters, Valleys and even place galiciers. Then you have the time settings. A 1900's Chicago style, A 1950'S New York Style, And a 2000s Houston Style. Then there is the animations of the construction of buildings. When you build your buildings they just don't appear out of no where tou actually see your sims get into their work trucks and start to construct the building. And if the building is of no use anmore it decays and doesn't turn into a huge big purple borded up mess. Then if you want to destroy or knock down a building it just doesn't disappear, you can actually impload or expload your buildings from any side you wish. There are no old buildings from SimCity 3000, The're totally new realistic looking buildings in SimCity 4.To me all this extra stuff makes this game totally anew. You won't get board if you like Simulation games.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
29, 2016
												I first played SimCity 4 in 2005 and instantly fell in love with it. Back then, I clocked in hundreds of hours of playtime and to this day it remains my favorite city builder of all time.The graphics, although they may appear a little dated to modern eyes, still hold up exceptionally well.The most important aspect, the gameplay, is just as great as it was back in the day. You can create everything from a polluted industrial wasteland to a shining metropolitan utopia and everything in between. Although easy to learn, the game can be quite complex: you can manage everything from the topography to transportation routes in your city.Although a minor point, it's worth mentioning that SimCity 4's soundtrack is superb. It definitely contributes to the game.Additionally, there is still an active modding community for this game. There are mods that add new buildings, transportation options, custom textures, and various other things that improve the game overall.One minor criticism I have is that a little work is required to get everything running properly on modern hardware, but there are a couple of guides available on the community hub for this. After tinkering with Steam's launch options for a few minutes, I had no further issues.Overall, I highly recommend SimCity 4, especially if you like city builders. It is a classic and easily one of the best examples of its genre.

content:
, 2014
												     How does one go about writing a review for something like this? To some it feels like DLC for Simcity 3000, for others it's an amazing stand-alone title. So what about me, where do I stand? I reside in the latter category beliveing this is an amazing game on its own. But how amazing? Ladies, gentlemen, and others, my name is Mlobitz and welcome to this review. Today, Simcity 4. Let's jam! And yes I did just quote Arkada, DEAL WITH IT.     When I was still 11 and browsing the Steam Summer Sale of 2013 (roughly a year ago) and a game caught my attention. You see, at the time I was obsessed with what I called them "Retro Games" and all the history they might hold. One of my favorite games from the NES/SNES era was Simcity. Rather simple but very rewarding and interesting, the original Simcity melted away countless hours of 5th Grade (when I was still 10). So when I saw Simcity 4 on Steam for $5.99 I hade to check it out.      Starting out, I had a hard time figuring out what to do, this is no simple game to learn. The in-game tutorials aren't very helpful except for teaching you the bare-basics of the game. I had to watch a large amount of YouTube videos to be remotely successful. Math is also required to make effective grids whether you use unit distace or cost to measure length of roads or avenues. To even get skyscapers in your city and make it look like a city, you need extensive knowledge and mastery of the game's concepts. One example of this was when my technology teacher let us play Simcity 4 on her computers every once in a while (she's an awesome teacher by the way), most of the students ended up skipping the tutorial and spamming disasters on barren terrain. One of my friends who played through the tutorials couldn't sustain a good income and generally didn't know what he was doing.  Accessibility gets a below average 4.2 out of 10.     On to the good bits! When I finally got things up and running the game became challenging yet addicting and rewarding, I also felt proud when my city was filled with plenty of houses, shops and factories. The GUI can be hard to learn but once you get used to it it's efficient contains everyhting it needs to and more! It's cool when your perfectly laid-out grid is functioning perfectly while also being pretty.The journey to getting your city to this state is highly enjoyable and satisfying. One of the biggest things that makes this game so much fun to play is region gameplay. This lets you connect your cities and let them share resources such as power and water. This allows certain cities to provide certain things while being kept alive by other cities while keeping them alive. Maybe a city based around power getting water from a city based around water. Being as great as it is, gameplay gets a very good 8.6 out of 10.     In terms of visuals there's not much to cover, for a 2D game in 2003 it's pretty standard fare. Although some 3D models like cars planes, and helicopters are a nice addition. zooming in reveals a lot of little details maxis has included like a giant spinning pizza at the pizza restaurant and clotheslines in houses' backyards. skyscrapers have and other large builings have little details like a pool near the top floor. Visuals gets a strong 7.8 out of 10.     As for the music, I'm gonna come right out and say it, this my favorite video game soundtrack of all time. The music not only fits the game fantastically any track is amazing music to listen to while doing something like schoolwork or.... other schoolwork! Yeah.... Check out the whole soundtrack on YouTube, you owe it to yourself to do so. This soundtrack a masterpiece, so it gets a well deserved 10 out of 10.     After finding the mean of all my scores, SImcity 4 recieves a respectable 7.65 out of 10.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 13, 2014
												If you are looking for a city builder with extremely well designed mechanics and gameplay, Sim City 4 is the game, without question.Cities XL, other generic clones, and even Sim City 5, shouldn't even be compared with Sim City 4. You may think like "Let's be honest, it's outdated.", and you would be so wrong. It is not, and probably won't be outdated, just like Mario Bros, Tetris, or Pac-Man.. Sim City is the very first initial applicaton of city building (both in terms of management mechanics and sandbox mode.), and Sim City 4 is the absolute peak of series. While even vanillia game is a very good experience, various mods which are still being created (After +10 years the game is released.)(Which on it's own is a proof of how well mechanics are made.) regularly, provides you anything you could ever wish for.I almost can't find any possible upgrade ideas for Sim City 4 (While some mods are included.), except some graphical fidelity - and the fact that these 10 year old graphics are exceptionally good for its time (You can apply some recent HD texture packs, too!), it won't be bothering you at all. Actually, in my opinion, 2,5D graphics are pretty optimal for such game. There are some pretty obvious cases like Stronghold Crusader & Stronghold II / StarCraft:BW & StarCraft 2, where 2,5D to 3D transition actually killed the uniqueness of gameplay. Even in the case of SC, when I exclude the mechanical differences of SC5 with SC4, gameplay is also kind of degraded. With so much going on in terms of gameplay, you may, and probably will be looking for some simplicity in terms of graphics which lightens the load in your brain, and SC4 has that.If you are someone who is looking for a top quality city building game, here is the absolute starting line.If you are someone who is into that genre, and you didn't played SC4...well...better late than never!

content:
9, 2012
												This game is one of the greatest games I've ever played in my entire life. I've found countless hours of repeated playthroughs of huge, sprawling, and picture-realistic cities. Each time I found myself getting better and better by the minute. This game by far makes SC2013, the recently "incredible" game EA released for the franchise, look like an ant. Plus, this was released about the same time Maxis was purchased out by EA, so it's not been infested by their evil deeds and their gruesome marketing schemes. Anyways, back to the game... There's so much to do in it! Though it IS by fact an old game, this game stands the test of time because it's probably one of the most played Sim Cities still in the franchise, being matched by SC2000 (Don't get me wrong, the games before SC4 in my honest opinion were also golden games, they all sooth my needs for a wonderous city construction game). It started off a bit shabby when it was first released, but when they pumped the Rush Hour pack into it, man oh man, the game was 1,000 times better! Not only that, but if you search around the web, you can find loads and loads and LOADS of addons, mods, and other things for the game to make your experience grand. Currently, I have over 250 mods in my game which consist of buildings of all sorts, land reskins, huge road addons for mega highways, and so much more! I know I seem like I'm boasting far too much about this game, but it's really this good. Hell, I'm probably underrating it for all I know, because this game is amazing!

content:
er 18, 2011
												Welcome to Sim City 4. In my humble opinion, this product right here is the pinnacle of city building simulator games humanity has ever been able to create. Don't be blindsided by later releases of this franchise or any other city building franchise for that mater. Sim City 4 builds upon previous entries in the franchise and doesn't fail to deliver. Neglect the fact that its old, it still looks fantastic and runs well on modern and old systems alike.You might ask yourself: city building must sure be boring. You little fool, you have no idea what you're missing. Planning out industrial, residential, commercial office zones, watching them grow, setting up hospitals, fire, police and schools so the city can evolve, planning out streets, roads, highways, mass transit systems, water, trash, energy so the city can live... this game has it all. I won't go into detail as there would be too much to tell, but its worthy to mention that in the end, you can crash all your hard work by calling a giant robot to destroy the city... or maybe spawning a volcano in the middle of downtown. Tornados and meteorites are classics too.There's always plenty to do in sim city, if any game should grab your attention, this should certainly be one of them.

content:
er 3, 2015
												This game is very fun and enjoyable. Improving on the great Simcity 2000, everything is classic Simcity with improved graphcs. (looks 3D enough to be considered modern, though the resolution is not the best) I consider it the last game of the classic series. The newer Simcity games deviated from the classics a bit. In this game you play as the mayor of a city, building roads, power plants, police stations, schools to satisfy your citizens while maintaining a balanced budget. The schools and hospitals are similar to games of its genre. The transportation options are really detailed. You will have different types of roads, railways, ferry, bus and subway. You can also connect to neighboring cities, buying garbage capacity, water, and electricity. There is a little addition that allow you to control vehicles and complete missions on your streets. I consider it a small enhancement, not really important but sometimes giving you nice bonus cash to ease the game out a bit.The only thing I am not able to recommend is the price. $20 for a game from 2003 is not justifiable. The game goes on sale for $5 during holidays. Would recommend buying it during sales.

content:
2011
												The classic and original Sim game - as good as it gets minus performance issues. SimCity 4 offers great replayability and complexity, with an insane amount of player-created content available on the internet. The learning curve is less than linear, with basic city building as easy as it has ever been, but end-game being at least as complicated as it has ever been (GameFAQs has some good write-ups to help newbies). The only notable drawback (other than tame gameplay, but hey, it's a SIM!) is how poorly SimCity performs on budget and entry-level PCs. Just lower the default settings to the lowest and slowly crank them up and you won't have a problem.

content:
, 2011
												Simcity 4 was, and still is, the best city-planning simulator.It have very deep game mechanics, which ensure the city simulation is dynamic. It is nearly impossible to just "pan out"more zones without many different issues. Most of these issues will have  affect on the population, and this would cause other issues, etc. All the city planning simulators came after it failed to reach its level in terms of complexity. And it is friendly toward beginners. ( Hint: After go wild building for a while, you may want to go back to check the tutorials.) Its graphic is outdated.The game engine is not very effective. (One of the devs explained that is because the game was built before DirectX 9) The camera is fixed. Look at the screenshots and determine yourself. The game is "moddable". The UI and the engine can not be edited. But all the data and the models are. This results in a great collection of building (and other thing on ground) mods. Most of them requires manual install, and sometimes need additional dependency. They can be found on Simtropolis or SC4devotion.com.The most important mod for Simcity 4 is Network Addon Mod, or NAM. It is a great improvement, if not overhaul, of traffic system. I recommend anyone who plan spending more than 10 hours on this game to install it. Due to engine restrictions, build a tram-in-avenue/tram-on-road interchange or underground tunnel is more complex than it should. But at least you can do it, with patience and time.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
23, 2011
												From Cities XL to Sim City: Societies, pretenders to the throne have come and gone, but none can truly challenge SimCity 4.As the final franchise installment before the sale to EA, SC4 represents everything Maxis learned about the city-building genre they single-handedly created, quite appropriately, from nothing. It is meticulous without pedantry. It is involved without perplexity. It is engaging without gimmicks. Timeless graphics paired to a funky, soulful soundtrack bring it all to a mirror shine.Sim City 4 is not just a shining example of wisdom distilled through generations; Sim City 4 is inspired requiem for a masterful developer.9/10.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
22, 2014
												It's now 2014 and this is still the best city building game out there. Sure the graphics are outdated but every other aspect of the game is superior to more modern titles. Despite being old, the graphics are still pretty decent (actually supports HD widescreen, just google it) and you'll find yourself sometimes zooming in to buildings just to admire the details. Although the game is simple to pick up, its deceptively difficult. It takes practice and planning to grow your towns into cities into bustling metropolitans. The mechanics are complex and challenging but also very rewarding to master. I have logged hundreds of hours on this game over the years creating vast multi-city regions.Once you think you've covered all of the game, finally grew some elusive skyscrapers (or whatever your goal is), there is still a plethora of mods available to you. Whether you want real life buildings, fantasy buildings, custom regions (some created using real life data), or advanced networking/traffic capabilities, there is something for everyone. This game is now 10+ years old and there is still custom content being created on nearly a daily basis. What other game has this much longevity?It's by far one of the best simulation games ever made in any genre.

content:
23, 2011
												From Cities XL to Sim City: Societies, pretenders to the throne have come and gone, but none can truly challenge SimCity 4.As the final franchise installment before the sale to EA, SC4 represents everything Maxis learned about the city-building genre they single-handedly created, quite appropriately, from nothing. It is meticulous without pedantry. It is involved without perplexity. It is engaging without gimmicks. Timeless graphics paired to a funky, soulful soundtrack bring it all to a mirror shine.Sim City 4 is not just a shining example of wisdom distilled through generations; Sim City 4 is inspired requiem for a masterful developer.9/10.

												I've played SimCity Creator and SimCity DS and thought they were pretty good. I've played those games in my childhood and I still play them on occasion for nostaliga. When I came across this ancient relic, I thought "Wow, what an old game. It must be pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥."I thought indeed. After I played the tutorial, I learned that this is much better and more complex than the two SimCitys I have played in the past, and was very suprised to the capabilities it had. The other two had came out almost 6 years after this game had released and are very, and I mean VERY, more primative and basic than this game. About 1 1/2 hours later, I realized that the other two are absolute ♥♥♥♥ing horrible teir, and this one is god teir.So, in my conclusion, I would give this an 7/10 so far. The last two have spoiled me with their easy gameplay and basic understandments. But, with more expirence and gametime with this improved game, I shall hopefully give it a higher score the next time I sit down and review this masterpiece.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												I haven't played the latest Sim City, but I've played all the rest. This is by far, my most favorite version. This gives you all the features that you expect out of a Sim city builder game. You zone land for the three basic types in your city: residential, commercial, and industrial. Each of the three zones has three subcategories. For example, you can pick an agricultural zone for industrial or medium density, which will allow small shops and factories. Same goes for the other core zones. Placement of services is critical in the city. Police stations, fire stations, and hospital proximity to things is all important. But your sims want more than just the essentials. They want soccer fields, plazas, playgrounds, and tennis courts as well. Again, where these units are placed is critical. Each thing you make costs a build amount and a monthly upkeep, so thought must go into it. As does how much road you have and of what type. You can eventually add rail, boats, planes, and a myriad of other additions to the pulse of the city. I have a few gripes with the game though (all minor). One, the camera controls could be smoother. Two, WASD should be the primary camera control instead of the arrow keys (the game shows its age here). And three, I wish the game had more organic choices for laying roads and placement of zones. All things snap to the grid and diaganol roads have a funny bend to them. These have nothing to do with the enjoyment of the game though.Sim City is a relaxed, leisurely game to play.

content:
y 9, 2015
												You would not believe the hours I put into this timeless classic, I must of spent thousands of hours on this when I was young. SimCity 4 and Age of Mythology where the two games that got me into gaiming. I ♥♥♥♥♥♥ LOVE this game!. The graphics are dated but what do you excpect from a game made in 2003. The game has endless replay-ability. From constructing mega cities to making small towns piled beneath 120 tons worth of nappies and crisp packets, this game is the best simcity out there. In my opinion.The game has the ability to do contract work like flying a helicopter to writing swear words in the sky or chasing down a bank robber in a police car like robocop. I can't even begin to try to comprehend how they coded this as it baffles my mind. This game brings me back to the days where people waitied for games to come out and didn't just demand a broken game.All the time when I played this game I had no idea the amount of mods that are out there. The modding community is one of the most active modding community I have seen since a Bethesda game. Theres no need for city limit extensions either the game comes with a massive border even for litte plots. What I always do is make cities into parts like East and West and they look awesome from the region view. You can edit the land, have military bases next to rocket launches and, and, and...I could go on about this game for days on end it looks like I already have. So just buy it nomatter what price. £9.99 is still too little for this timeless classic.∞/10Would put down 10 Tokyoo Towers again.

content:
er 2, 2014
****1/5
4.5 out of 5City Builder of its time.Simcity 4 is the fourth followup in the detailed and engaging city builder series Simcity. Simcity 3000 and 4 are the only the ones I've played and generally see them on par as each other, whilst Simcity 4 is more detailed, there are some certain quirks that I dislike about 4 (i.e. vanishing traffic).However, like Simcity 3000, Simcity 4 bathes in interaction, immersive sound and introspection. The game is highly polished compared to other recent city builder games (City Life series I'm looking at you), and although lacks a proper 3D engine has a definite charm to it. In short if you've never played city builders, this is your best place to start.

												Ignore all of those bad reviews that pop up now and then, they're probably just people who have bad computers/brains. Anyhow, really fun game. Graphics aren't bad, even though they're mainly 2D, they're made to look like 3D. The gameplay is awesome, too. I remember playing this as a kid, I would literally rush for a large city with skyscrapers using landmark towers and stuff. Because at the time, I didnt really know too much about the game, but I kept failing, and kept playing. That's how good the game was. Games like Master of Olympus and Simcity 4 are the reasons why I am playing games today. Without these games in my childhood, I probably wouldn't be sitting here writing a review about it. I recommend to all who want a Simcity with decent graphics and gameplay, on a balance. It's got better graphics than 3000, and better gameplay than Simcity 2013.

content:
y 8, 2015
												Oh how I was missing this game of my account...After the last SimCity... Mess? I honestly forgot how amazing the previous SimCity games were! I used to play SimCity 3000 UK but I've never played SimCity 4. Although this is a bit dated now, it is still amazing, the landscaping works really well, the roads, tracks, motorways etc work nicely and the buildings and structures are pretty nice models seems this game states it was released in 2003.The graphics are good, Obviously a little dated but... You'd know that, the only thing I wish it had in video settings was 1080p. [ READ BELOW ]-- UPDATE: Thanks to user "Damon Gant", you can go to 1080p easily, you need to go into "Launch Options" and type / copy & paste "-CustomResolution:enabled -r1920x1080x32". Works brilliantly, Icons are a little small but still clear.One extra little thing I liked was the ability to play as a Sim inside your city... Driving a car, truck, boat, helicopter andplane... This doesn't seem to add anything useful to the game but it's a nice feature to have!Only things I don't like about this game are the fact that bridges can't go diagonal and the building zones can't go diagonal.I think this game is near-perfect, Noticed no bugs, glitches, freezes or crashes. I'd also imagine that majority of people can play this as it isn't a demanding game.This is now my favourite City building game, It was CitiesXL but that game has annoying bugs etc.-- Side note after playing a couple hours. You'll need to save your game every so often, this game does crash.. Probably an issue with Windows 7? No Idea! - This isn't a huge issue aslong as you remember to save!

content:
y 29, 2014
												This is the last "Good" Sim City game. You start with a Region, in the real world. You make a town in that region. You than make another town in that region. Both towns can now make deals with each other to sutain one another. That, is how close you can be as a State Governer if you manage to occupy every city territory in the entire region. There is also some early "The Sims" to the short lived social massivly multiplayer game "Sims Online". Yeah, so if you had the origanal "The Sims", you can "import" that charater to be an individual "Blessed by the god, known as Mayor" in your city. A rather unused feature. The only problem is people in this game don't like to use public transit, even if you forced them. Commercal zones don't quite develope or have enough demand and job creation. Also everything has to be severly under budget to stay in the green, even if the Sims go to school, they don't really go to school to justify 200 student capacity and 15 teachers when only 17 attend. It would just be cheaper with no schools and emergancy services even if the advisers ♥♥♥♥ and moan. All problems non-existant in Sim City 3000.

content:
11, 2014
												This game may be old, but this I think is it's saving grace. It's moddable beyond anything a modern games maker would even consider, letting you change traffic simulation, train, plane and ferry skins, add buildings, add HD textures, alter the way a city needs to grow, you name it. And installation of said mods is child's play, simply downloading files into a plugin folder. And because of it's age the sheer amount of mods out there is insane. The community is still alive and kicking after 11 years, which tells you something about the longevity of this game. If you like city builders then look no further, Maxis set the bar with this one and it has yet to be beaten.

content:
er 27, 2011
												SimCity…The definitive city building game…The time show on steam doesn’t show the amount of time I have spent since I bought the game in 2004. As a matter of fact, I have gone through about 5 copies of this game…SimCity4 has infinite replay value. No 2 cities will be the same…..don’t even attempt to make a duplicate city…it will not work.Simcity4 works a little differently from the previous version of SimCity in that, where the previous versions just gave you a plot of land to build on, SC4 lets you select a region, akin to a city or county in your state. You can import and export among the regions, sell electricity, water and import garbage. Build a police station with a helipad and be a helicopter pilot stopping crimes. Build a hospital with a helipad, and deliver a liver for a transplant. Build a small airfield and  spray crops for insects, or write messages in the sky. Built an airport, and watch the tourism tax dollars start rolling in…

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
28, 2013
												Probably the best city building, management and simulator ever made. Extremely detailed, with lots and lots of well done prerendered graphics (the world, cars and some objects are 3D though, so it doesn't ruin the presentation at all). It's the deepest SimCity, and it's also the hardest: you'll really need to grow your city slowly and watch the taxes, or else you'll be bankrupt in no time. But if you're patient, you'll be rewarded with hours and hours of fun. It's good to be the Mayor!There are some problems though. For example, no widescreen support and flawed transit (both can be fixed by mods). Also the game has some compatibility issues with newer systems and 64 bit Windows, so you'll have to use software mode and put some graphics options on medium and low.Other small flaws are: the driving minigames (you can drive cars, helicopters, planes and even a tank on missions around the city), which are a bit annoying, and can become frustrating due to city traffic and sudden failures. Nowhere near as good as what Streets of SImCity did with SC2000's maps. And the other small problem is that  it tries to mimic the graphic style of The Sims, so most cities will look the same. Still, it's good that they didn't casualize the game to the max back then in 2003, trying to appeal to The Sims audience. Instead, we got the most complex SimCity to date, and I recommend it.
